Just found out if you operate a canadian outfitters boat you will need a boaters safety card. online test is $30 in Wisconsin;It takes at least 3 hrs to complete

The boater safety card rule is that if you operate a boat in Canada for more than 45 days you need a boaters safety card. If you rent a boat ,say for a week. the rental aggrement will state that the fella that rented the boat to you went over the safe operation of the craft. This will be the same as a card. If your a Canadain operating your own boat you will need a card. This is dependent on where the boat is registered. If it has a U.S. regestration your under the 45 day rule, meaning that if you in Canada for more than 45 days you need the card, if under 45 days you need nothing. If it's Canadain you need the card or rental aggement without reguard to length of stay.

The 45 day rule applies to the person and/or the boat. If you store your boat in Canada for a season, you'll need an operator card or other proof of competency.The regs don't state this clearly in most cases, but I did contact Transport Canada directly and had a supervisor interpret the regulations for me.The MNDNR does a boater safety card through the mail for free. Some of our seasonal guests got their card from MN that way last summer.Also, an outfitter can provide the renters checklist or not. Some may choose to only rent to those that have the card or proof of competency. If you rent boats through your outfitter, you may want to confirm that the checklist will be available if you do not have a card.
